elements.title: hyperbolic (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the spirals in photographs of spiral staircases (example pictured) are hyperbolic?

elements.title: Forest Van Hook (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Forest Van Hook was so large that he always bought two tickets when attending sports events?

elements.title: a song about a horror game (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a My Little Pony fan band wrote a song about a horror game, creating what has been considered to be a sub-genre of music?

elements.title: Anton Charles Pegis (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that by popular demand, philosopher Anton Charles Pegis continued to teach graduate classes for three years after becoming an emeritus professor?

elements.title: Tony Tribe (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the reggae singer Tony Tribe used to have blouses thrown at him while performing?

elements.title: al-Wafa bi Asma al-Nisa (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Akram Nadwi addressed the lack of Islamic women scholars highlighted in a Time article by composing al-Wafa bi Asma al-Nisa, a 43-volume work with more than 10,000 entries?

elements.title: Roar-o-Saurus (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that despite being only 40 feet (12 m) tall, Roar-o-Saurus was described by CNN as one of the "most insane" new roller coasters of 2014?

elements.title: William Carter (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that composer and conductor William Carter began a career as a professional organist at the age of nine?
